14.19: “Another said, ‘I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I am going to prove them. I ask you to excuse me.’
14.20: “Still another said, ‘I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.’
14.21: “The servant came and reported this to his master. Then the master of the house in anger said to his servant, ‘Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in here the poor and the maimed and the lame and the blind.’
14.22: “The servant said, ‘Master, what you commanded has been done, and yet there is room.’
14.23: “Then the master said to the servant, ‘Go out to the highways and hedges, and compel them to come in, so that my house may be filled.
14.24: For I tell you, none of those men who were invited shall taste my supper.’ ”
14.25: Large crowds went with Him. And He turned and said to them,
14.26: “If anyone comes to Me and does not hate his father and mother and wife and children and brothers and sisters, yes, and even his own life, he cannot be My disciple.
14.27: And whoever does not bear his cross and follow Me cannot be My disciple.
14.28: “For who among you, intending to build a tower, does not sit down first and count the cost to see whether he has resources to complete it?
14.29: Otherwise, perhaps, after he has laid the foundation and is not able to complete it, all who see it will begin to mock him,
14.30: saying, ‘This man began to build and was not able to complete it.’
14.31: “Or what king, going to wage war against another king, does not sit down first and take counsel whether he is able with ten thousand to meet him who comes against him with twenty thousand?
14.32: Otherwise, while the other is yet at a distance, he sends a delegation and requests conditions of peace.
14.33: So likewise, any of you who does not forsake all that he has cannot be My disciple.
14.34: “Salt is good. But if the salt has lost its saltiness, how shall it be made salty?
14.35:
It is fit neither for the land nor for the manure pile. So men throw it out.
“He who has ears to hear, let him hear.”

15.1: Now all the tax collectors and sinners drew near to Him to hear Him.
15.2: But the Pharisees and scribes murmured, saying, “This Man receives sinners and eats with them.”
15.3: So He told them this parable, saying,
15.4: “What man among you having a hundred sheep and losing one of them does not leave the ninety-nine in the wilderness and go after the one which is lost until he finds it?
15.5: And when he has found it, he places it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
15.6: Then when he comes home, he calls together his friends and neighbors, saying to them, ‘Rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep which was lost.’
15.7: Likewise, I tell you, there will be more joy in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous men who need no repentance.
15.8: “Or what woman, having ten silver coins and losing one, does not light a candle and sweep the house and search diligently until she finds it?
15.9: And when she has found it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, ‘Rejoice with me, for I have found the coin which I had lost.’
15.10: Likewise, I tell you, there is joy in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner who repents.”
15.11: Then He said, “A man had two sons.
15.12: The younger of them said to his father, ‘Father, give me the share of the property that falls to me.’ So he divided his estate between them.
15.13: “Not many days later, the younger son gathered everything together, and journeyed to a distant country, and there squandered his possessions in prodigal living.
15.14: When he had spent everything, there came a severe famine in that country, and he began to be in want.
15.15: So he went and hired himself to a citizen of that county, who sent him into his fields to feed swine.
15.16: He would gladly have filled his stomach with the husks that the swine were eating, but no one gave him any.
15.17: “When he came to himself, he said, ‘How many of my father’s hired servants have an abundance of bread, and here I am perishing with hunger!
15.18: I will arise and go to my father, and I will say to him, “Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you.
15.19: I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Make me like one of your hired servants.” ’
15.20:
So he arose and came to his father.
“But while he was yet far away, his father saw him and was moved with compassion, and ran and embraced his neck and kissed him.
15.21: “The son said to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy to be called your son.’
15.22: “But the father said to his servants, ‘Bring out the best robe and put it on him. And put a ring on his hand and shoes on his feet.
15.23: Bring here the fattened calf and kill it, and let us eat and be merry.
15.24: For this son of mine was dead, and is alive again; he was lost, and is found.’ So they began to be merry.
15.25: “Now his older son was in the field. As he came and drew near the house, he heard music and dancing.
15.26: So he called one of the servants and asked what this meant.
15.27: He said to him, ‘Your brother has come, and your father has killed the fattened calf, because he has received him safe and sound.’
15.28: “He was angry and would not go in. Therefore his father came out and entreated him.
15.29: But he answered his father, ‘Look! These many years have I served you. Nor have I ever transgressed your commands, yet never have you given me a goat, so that I might be merry with my friends.
15.30: But when this son of yours came, who has devoured your living with harlots, you killed the fattened calf for him.’
15.31: “He said to him, ‘Son, you are always with me, and all that I have is yours.
15.32: But it was fitting to be merry and be glad, for this brother of yours was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.’ ”

16.1: He told His disciples: “There was a rich man who had a steward who was accused to the man of wasting his resources.
16.2: So he called him and said, ‘How is it that I hear this about you? Give an account of your stewardship, for you may no longer be steward.’
16.3: “Then the steward said to himself, ‘What shall I do, for my master is taking away the stewardship from me? I cannot dig. I am ashamed to beg.
16.4: I know what to do so that, when I am removed from the stewardship, others may receive me into their houses.’
16.5: “So he called each of his master’s debtors, and said to the first, ‘How much do you owe my master?’
16.6:
“He said, ‘Eight hundred gallons of oil.’
“He said to him, ‘Take your bill, and sit down quickly and write four hundred.’
16.7:
“Then he said to another, ‘And how much do you owe?’
“He said, ‘One thousand bushels of wheat.’
“He said to him, ‘Take your bill, and write eight hundred.’
16.8: “The master commended the dishonest steward, because he had acted prudently. For the sons of this world are wiser in their own generation than the sons of light.
16.9: I say to you, make friends for yourself by means of unrighteous wealth, so that when you fall short, they may receive you into eternal dwellings.
16.10: “He who is faithful in what is least is faithful also in much. And he who is dishonest in the least is dishonest also in much.
16.11: So if you have not been faithful in the unrighteous wealth, who will commit to your trust the true riches?
16.12: And if you have not been faithful in that which is another man’s, who will give you that which is your own?
16.13: “No servant can serve two masters. Either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be loyal to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and wealth.”
16.14: The Pharisees, who were lovers of money, heard all these things and derided Him.
16.15: He said to them, “You are those who justify yourselves before men, but God knows your hearts. For that which is highly esteemed before men is an abomination before God.
16.16: “The Law and the Prophets were preached until John. Since then the kingdom of God has been preached, and everyone is pressing into it.
16.17: It is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one stroke of the law to fail.
16.18: “Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and whoever marries her who is divorced by her husband commits adultery.
16.19: “There was a rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen and fared sumptuously every day.
16.20: There was also a beggar named Lazarus, covered with sores, who had been placed at his gate,
16.21: desiring to be fed the crumbs falling from the rich man’s table. Moreover the dogs came and licked his sores.
16.22: “It came to pass that the beggar died and was carried by the angels to Abraham’s presence. The rich man also died and was buried.
16.23: In Hades, being in torment, he lifted up his eyes and saw Abraham from a distance and Lazarus in his presence.
16.24: So he cried out, ‘Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue. For I am tormented in this flame.’
16.25: “But Abraham said, ‘Son, remember that you in your lifetime received your good things, and Lazarus in like manner evil things. But now he is comforted and you are tormented.
16.26: And besides all this, between us and you there is a great gulf, so that those who would pass from here to you cannot, nor can those from there pass to us.’
16.27: “He said, ‘Then I pray you, father, to send him to my father’s house,
16.28: for I have five brothers, to testify to them, lest they also come to this place of torment.’
16.29: “Abraham said to him, ‘They have Moses and the Prophets. Let them hear them.’
16.30: “He said, ‘No, father Abraham. But if someone from the dead goes to them, they will repent.’
16.31: “He said to him, ‘If they do not hear Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be persuaded if someone should rise from the dead.’ ”

17.1: Then He said to the disciples, “It is impossible except that offenses will come. But woe to him through whom they come!
17.2: It would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck and he was thrown into the sea, than to offend one of these little ones.
17.3:
Take heed to yourselves.
“If your brother sins against you, rebuke him. And if he repents, forgive him.
17.4: If he sins against you seven times in a day, and seven times in a day turns to you, saying, ‘I repent,’ you must forgive him.”
17.5: The apostles said to the Lord, “Increase our faith.”
17.6: The Lord said, “If you had faith as a grain of mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree, ‘Be uprooted and be planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you.
17.7: “Which of you, having a servant plowing or herding sheep, will say to him when he has come in from the field, ‘Come now and sit down for dinner’?
17.8: Will he not rather say to him, ‘Prepare my supper, and dress yourself and serve me until I eat and drink. And afterward you will eat and drink’?
17.9: Does he thank the servant because he did what was commanded? I think not.
17.10: So you also, when you have done everything commanded you, say, ‘We are unprofitable servants. We have done our duty.’ ”
17.11: As Jesus went to Jerusalem, He passed between Samaria and Galilee.
17.12: As He entered a village, there met Him ten men who were lepers, who stood at a distance.
17.13: They lifted up their voices, saying, “Jesus, Master, have pity on us!”
17.14: When He saw them, He said to them, “Go, show yourselves to the priests.” And as they went, they were cleansed.
17.15: One of them, when he saw that he was healed, returned with a loud voice glorifying God,
17.16: and fell down on his face at His feet, giving Him thanks. And he was a Samaritan.
17.17: Jesus said, “Were not the ten cleansed? Where are the nine?
17.18: Were there not any found to return and give glory to God except this foreigner?”
17.19: Then He said to him, “Rise, go your way. Your faith has made you well.”
17.20: When He was asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, He answered them, “The kingdom of God does not come with observation.
17.21: Nor will they say, ‘Here it is!’ or ‘There it is!’ For remember, the kingdom of God is within you.”
17.22: Then He said to the disciples, “The days will come when you will desire to see one of the days of the Son of Man, but you will not see it.
17.23: They will say to you, ‘Look here,’ or ‘Look there!’ Do not follow after them.
17.24: For as the lightning flashes and lights up the heavens from one side to the other, so will the Son of Man be in His day.
17.25: But first He must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.
17.26: “Just as it was in the days of Noah, so will it be in the days of the Son of Man.
17.27: They were eating, drinking, marrying, and were given in marriage until the day when Noah entered the ark. Then the flood came and destroyed them all.
17.28: “Likewise as it was in the days of Lot: They ate, they drank, they bought, they sold, they planted, they built.
17.29: But on the day that Lot departed from Sodom, fire and brimstone rained from heaven and destroyed them all.
17.30: “So will it be on the day when the Son of Man is revealed.
17.31: On that day let him who is on the housetop, with his goods in the house, not come down to take them away. And likewise let him who is in the field not return to the things behind.
17.33: Whoever seeks to save his life will lose it, and whoever loses his life will preserve it.
17.34: I tell you, on that night two men will be in one bed; the one will be taken and the other will be left.
17.35: Two women will be grinding grain together; the one will be taken and the other will be left.
17.36: Two men will be in the field; the one will be taken and the other will be left.”
17.37:
They asked, “Where, Lord?”
He replied, “Where the body is, there the eagles will be gathered together.”

18.1: He told them a parable to illustrate that it is necessary always to pray and not lose heart.
18.2: He said: “In a city there was a judge who did not fear God or regard man.
18.3: And a widow was in that city. She came to him, saying, ‘Avenge me against my adversary.’
18.4: “He would not for a while. Yet afterward he said to himself, ‘Though I do not fear God or respect man,
18.5: yet because this widow troubles me, I will avenge her, lest by her continual coming she will weary me.’ ”
18.6: And the Lord said, “Hear what the unjust judge says.
18.7: And shall not God avenge His own elect and be patient with them, who cry day and night to Him?
18.8: I tell you, He will avenge them speedily. Nevertheless, when the Son of Man comes, will He find faith on the earth?”
18.9: He told this parable to some who trusted in themselves, as though they were righteous, and despised others:
18.10: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, the one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.
18.11: The Pharisee stood and prayed these things about himself, ‘God, I thank You that I am not like other men: extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even like this tax collector.
18.12: I fast twice a week, and I tithe of all that I earn.’
18.13: “But the tax collector, standing at a distance, would not even lift his eyes to heaven, but struck his chest, saying, ‘God, be merciful to me a sinner.’
18.14: “I tell you, this man went down to his house justified rather than the other. For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted.”
18.15: They also brought infants to Him that He might touch them. When the disciples saw it, they rebuked them.
18.16: But Jesus called them to Him and said, “Permit the little children to come to Me, and do not hinder them. For to such belongs the kingdom of God.
18.17: Truly, I say to you, whoever will not receive the kingdom of God as a little child will in no wise enter it.”
18.18: A certain ruler asked Him, “Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?”
18.19: Jesus said to him, “Why do you call Me good? No one is good, except God alone.
18.20: You know the commandments: Do not commit adultery, Do not murder, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Honor your father and your mother.”
18.21: He said, “All these I have kept since my youth.”
18.22: When Jesus heard this, He said to him, “Yet you lack one thing. Sell all that you have and distribute to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. And come, follow Me.”
18.23: When he heard this he became very sorrowful, for he was very rich.
18.24: When Jesus saw that he became very sorrowful, He said, “How hard it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!
18.25: For it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God.”
18.26: Those who heard this said, “Who then can be saved?”
18.27: He said, “What is impossible with men is possible with God.”
18.28: Peter said, “Look, we have left everything and followed You.”
18.29: He said to them, “Truly, I tell you, there is no man who has left his home or parents or brothers or wife or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
18.30: who shall not receive many times more in this age and, in the age to come, eternal life.”
18.31: Taking the twelve, He said, “Listen! We are going up to Jerusalem, and everything that is written by the prophets concerning the Son of Man will be accomplished,
18.32: for He will be handed over to the Gentiles and will be mocked and insulted and spit upon.
18.33: They will scourge Him and put Him to death, and on the third day He will rise again.”
18.34: They understood none of these things. This saying was hidden from them, and they did not comprehend what was spoken.
18.35: As He was drawing near Jericho, a certain blind man sat along the way begging.
18.36: Hearing a crowd passing by, he asked what it meant.
18.37: They told him that Jesus of Nazareth was passing by.
18.38: He cried out, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”
18.39: Those who went in front rebuked him, so that he would keep quiet. But he cried out much more, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”
18.40: Jesus stood and commanded him to be brought to Him. When he came near, He asked him,
18.41:
“What do you want Me to do for you?”
He said, “Lord, grant that I may receive my sight.”
18.42: Jesus said to him, “Receive your sight. Your faith has saved you.”
18.43: Immediately he received his sight and followed Him, glorifying God. When all the people saw it, they gave praise to God.

19.1: Jesus entered and passed through Jericho.
19.2: A man was there named Zacchaeus who was a chief tax collector, and he was rich.
19.3: He tried to see who Jesus was, but was not able from the crowd, because he was little in stature.
19.4: So he ran ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see Him, for He was to pass that way.
19.5: When Jesus came to the vicinity, He looked up and saw him, and said to him, “Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for today I must remain at your house.”
19.6: So he hurried and came down, and received Him joyfully.
19.7: When they saw it, they all murmured, saying, “He has gone to be the guest of a man who is a sinner.”
19.8: But Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, “Look, Lord, I give half of my possessions to the poor. And if I have taken anything from anyone by false accusation, I will repay him four times as much.”
19.9: Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come to this house, because he also is a son of Abraham.
19.10: For the Son of Man has come to seek and to save that which was lost.”
19.11: As they heard these things, He continued and told them a parable, because He was near Jerusalem and because they thought the kingdom of God would immediately appear.
19.12: Therefore He said, “A nobleman went to a distant country to receive a kingdom and to return.
19.13: So he called his ten servants and entrusted to them ten pounds and said to them, ‘Trade until I come.’
19.14: “But his citizens hated him and sent a delegation after him, saying, ‘We do not want this man to reign over us.’
19.15: “When he returned, having received the kingdom, he summoned these servants, to whom he had entrusted the money, that he might know what everyone gained by trading.
19.16: “The first came, saying, ‘Master, your pound has made ten pounds more.’
19.17: “He said to him, ‘Well done, good servant! Because you have been faithful in very little, take authority over ten cities.’
19.18: “The second came, saying, ‘Master, your pound has made five pounds more.’
19.19: “He said in like manner to him, ‘You, take authority over five cities.’
19.20: “Then another came, saying, ‘Master, look, here is your pound, which I have kept put away in a napkin.
19.21: For I feared you, because you are an exacting man. You collect what you did not deposit, and reap what you did not sow.’
19.22: “He said to him, ‘Out of your own mouth will I judge you, you wicked servant. You knew that I was an exacting man, collecting what I did not deposit and reaping what I did not sow.
19.23: Why then did you not deposit my money in the bank, so that at my coming I might have collected it with interest?’
19.24: “Then he said to those who stood by, ‘Take the pound from him and give it to him who has ten pounds.’
19.25: “They said to him, ‘Master, he has ten pounds.’
19.26: “ ‘I tell you that to everyone who has will be given. But from him who has not, even what he has will be taken away from him.
19.27: But as for those enemies of mine, who would not let me reign over them, bring them here and slay them before me.’ ”
19.28: When He had said this, He went before them, ascending up to Jerusalem.
19.29: When He came near to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mountain called the Mount of Olives, He sent two of His disciples,
19.30: saying, “Go over into the village opposite you, where, as you enter, you will find a colt tied, on which no one has ever yet sat. Untie it and bring it here.
19.31: If anyone asks you, ‘Why are you untying it?’ you shall say to him, ‘Because the Lord has need of it.’ ”
19.32: Those who were sent went and found it just as He had told them.
19.33: As they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, “Why are you untying the colt?”
19.34: They said, “The Lord has need of it.”
19.35: They brought it to Jesus. And they threw their garments on the colt, and they set Jesus on it.
19.36: As He went, they spread their clothes in the street.
19.37: When He was coming near the descent of the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of the disciples began to rejoice and praise God with loud voices for all the mighty works that they had seen,
19.38:
saying:
‘Blessed is the King who comes in the name of the Lord!’
Peace in heaven and glory in the highest!”
19.39: Some of the Pharisees from the crowd said to Him, “Teacher, rebuke Your disciples.”
19.40: He answered them, “I tell you, if these should be silent, the stones would immediately cry out.”
19.41: When He came near, He beheld the city and wept over it,
19.42: saying, “If you, even you, had known even today what things would bring you peace! But now they are hidden from your eyes.
19.43: For the days will come upon you when your enemies will build an embankment around you and surround you, and press you in on every side.
19.44: They will dash you, and your children within you, to the ground. They will not leave one stone upon another within you, because you did not know the time of your visitation.”
19.45: Then He entered the temple and began to drive out those who sold and bought in it,
19.46: saying to them, “It is written, ‘My house will be a house of prayer,’ but you have made it ‘a den of thieves.’”
19.47: He taught daily in the temple. But the chief priests, the scribes, and the leaders of the people tried to kill Him.
19.48: Yet they could not find a way to do it, for all the people were very attentive to hear Him.

20.1: One day, as He taught the people in the temple and preached the gospel, the chief priests and the scribes with the elders came up to Him,
20.2: and said to Him, “Tell us, by what authority are You doing these things? Who is he who gave You this authority?”
20.3: He answered them, “I will also ask you one thing. Answer Me:
20.4: Was the baptism of John from heaven or from men?”
20.5: They debated with themselves, saying, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ He will say, ‘Why then did you not believe him?’
20.6: But if we say, ‘From men,’ all the people will stone us, for they are persuaded that John was a prophet.”
20.7: So they answered that they did not know where it was from.
20.8: Jesus said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.”
20.9: He began to tell the people this parable: “A man planted a vineyard, and leased it to vinedressers, and went to a distant country for a long time.
20.10: At harvest time he sent a servant to the vinedressers so they might give him some fruit of the vineyard. But the vinedressers beat him and sent him away empty-handed.
20.11: Again, he sent another servant. But they beat him also, and treated him shamefully, and sent him away empty-handed.
20.12: Once again, he sent a third. And they wounded him also and drove him out.
20.13: “Then the owner of the vineyard said, ‘What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Perhaps they will respect him when they see him.’
20.14: “But when the vinedressers saw him, they debated among themselves, saying, ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him, that the inheritance may be ours.’
20.15:
So they drove him out of the vineyard and killed him.
“What then will the owner of the vineyard do to them?
20.16:
He will come and kill these vinedressers and will give the vineyard to others.”
When they heard this, they said, “May it not be so!”
20.17:
He looked at them and said, “What then is this that is written:
‘The stone which the builders rejected
    has become the cornerstone’?
20.18: Whoever falls on that stone will be broken. But he on whom it falls will be crushed to powder.”
20.19: The chief priests and the scribes tried to lay their hands on Him that same hour, but they feared the people. For they perceived that He had told this parable against them.
20.20: They watched Him and sent out spies who pretended to be righteous men, that they might seize Him in His words to hand Him over to the power and authority of the governor.
20.21: So they asked Him, “Teacher, we know that You speak and teach rightly. And You do not show partiality, but You truly teach the way of God.
20.22: Is it lawful for us to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?”
20.23: He perceived their craftiness and said to them, “Why do you test Me?
20.24:
Show Me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have?”
They said, “Caesar’s.”
20.25: He said to them, “Then render to Caesar what is Caesar’s, and to God what is God’s.”
20.26: They could not catch Him in His words before the people. And they marveled at His answer and were silent.
20.27: Some of the Sadducees, who deny that there is any resurrection, came to Him and asked Him,
20.28: “Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man’s brother dies, having a wife but no children, then this man should take the wife and raise up children for his brother.
20.29: Now there were seven brothers. The first took a wife and died childless.
20.30: The second took her as wife, and he died childless.
20.31: And then the third took her, and in like manner, all seven died and left no children.
20.32: Last of all, the woman died also.
20.33: Therefore in the resurrection whose wife will she be? For the seven had her as a wife.”
20.34: Jesus answered them, “The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage.
20.35: But those who are counted worthy to attain that age, and the resurrection from the dead, neither marry nor are given in marriage.
20.36: For they cannot die any more, for they are equal to the angels and are the sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.
20.37: Now, at the bush, even Moses pointed out that the dead are raised when he called the Lord ‘the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’
20.38: For He is not the God of the dead, but of the living. For to Him all live.”
20.39: Some of the scribes said, “Teacher, You have spoken well.”
20.40: After that they dared not ask Him any question at all.
20.41: Then Jesus said to them, “How do they say that Christ is David’s Son?
20.42:
David himself says in the Book of Psalms,
‘The Lord said to my Lord,
    “Sit at My right hand,
20.43:
until I make Your enemies
    Your footstool.”’
20.44: David therefore calls Him ‘Lord.’ How is He then his Son?”
20.45: Then as all the people heard, He said to His disciples,
20.46: “Beware of the scribes who desire to walk in long robes and who love greetings in the marketplaces and the prominent seats in the synagogues and the seats of honor at banquets,
20.47: who devour widows’ houses and for a pretense make long prayers. They will receive greater condemnation.”

21.1: He looked up and saw the rich putting their gifts in the treasury.
21.2: He also saw a poor widow putting in two mites,
21.3: and He said, “Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put in more than all of them.
21.4: For all these out of their abundance have put in their gifts for God. But she out of her poverty has put in all the living she had.”
21.5: As some spoke of how the temple was adorned with beautiful stones and gifts, He said,
21.6: “As for these things which you see, the days will come when not one stone shall be left on another that will not be thrown down.”
21.7: They asked Him, “Teacher, when will these things be, and what will be the sign when this is about to happen?”
21.8: He said, “Beware lest you be deceived. For many will come in My name, saying, ‘I am He,’ and ‘The time has drawn near.’ Therefore do not go after them.
21.9: When you hear of wars and commotions, do not be afraid. For these things must first take place, but the end will not be at hand.”
21.10: Then He said to them, “Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
21.11: Great earthquakes will occur in various places, and there will be famines and pestilence. And there will be terrors and great signs from heaven.
21.12: “But before all these things, they will seize you and persecute you, delivering you up to the synagogues and prisons, and you will be brought before kings and governors for My name’s sake.
21.13: It will turn out as a testimony for you.
21.14: Therefore resolve in your hearts beforehand not to practice your defense.
21.15: For I will give you a mouth and wisdom, which all your opponents will be able to neither refute nor resist.
21.16: You will be betrayed by parents and brothers and relatives and friends. And they will put some of you to death.
21.17: You will be hated by all men for My name’s sake,
21.18: but not a hair of your head shall perish.
21.19: In your endurance you will gain your souls.
21.20: “When you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then you know that its desolation has drawn near.
21.21: Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, and let those who are in the city depart, and let not those who are in the country enter it.
21.22: For these are the days of vengeance, that all things which are written may be fulfilled.
21.23: But woe to those who are pregnant and to those who nurse in those days! For there will be great distress in the land and wrath upon this people.
21.24: They will fall by the edge of the sword and will be led away captive to all nations. And Jerusalem will be trampled on by the Gentiles until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.
21.25: “There will be signs in the sun and the moon and the stars; and on the earth distress of nations, with perplexity, the sea and the waves roaring;
21.26: men fainting from fear and expectation of what is coming on the inhabited earth. For the powers of heaven will be shaken.
21.27: Then they will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
21.28: When these things begin to happen, look up and lift up your heads, for your redemption is drawing near.”
21.29: He told them this parable: “Look at the fig tree, and all the trees.
21.30: When they are sprouting leaves already, you see and know for yourselves that summer is now near.
21.31: So in like manner, when you see these things happening, you know that the kingdom of God is near.
21.32: “Truly, I tell you, this generation will not pass away until all these things are fulfilled.
21.33: Heaven and earth will pass away, but My words will not pass away.
21.34: “Take heed to yourselves, lest your hearts become burdened by excessiveness and drunkenness and anxieties of life, and that Day comes on you unexpectedly.
21.35: For as a snare it will come on all those who dwell on the face of the whole earth.
21.36: Therefore watch always and pray that you may be counted worthy to escape all these things that will happen and to stand before the Son of Man.”
21.37: Each day He was teaching in the temple, and each night He went out and stayed on the mountain called the Mount of Olives.
21.38: And all the people came early in the morning to hear Him in the temple.

22.1: Now the Feast of Unleavened Bread, which is called the Passover, drew near.
22.2: And the chief priests and scribes were seeking how to kill Jesus, for they feared the people.
22.3: Then Satan entered into Judas, called Iscariot, who was one of the twelve.
22.4: He went and discussed with the chief priests and captains how he might betray Him to them.
22.5: They were glad and agreed to give him money.
22.6: He fully consented and searched for an opportunity to betray Him to them apart from the crowds.
22.7: Then the Day of Unleavened Bread came, when the Passover lamb must be killed.
22.8: He sent Peter and John, saying, “Go and prepare the Passover for us to eat it.”
22.9: They said to Him, “Where will You have us prepare it?”
22.10: He said to them, “Now, as you enter the city, a man carrying a pitcher of water will meet you there. Follow him into the house which he enters,
22.11: and say to the owner of the house, ‘The Teacher says to you, “Where is the guest room where I may eat the Passover with My disciples?” ’
22.12: He will show you a large furnished upper room. Prepare there.”
22.13: They went and found it as He had told them. So they prepared the Passover.
22.14: When the hour had come, He and the twelve apostles with Him sat down.
22.15: And He said to them, “I have earnestly desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.
22.16: For I tell you, I will never eat it again until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God.”
22.17: And He took the cup and gave thanks and said, “Take this and divide it among yourselves.
22.18: For I tell you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.”
22.19: Then He took the bread, and when He had given thanks, He broke it and gave it to them, saying, “This is My body which is given for you. Do this in remembrance of Me.”
22.20: In like manner, He took the cup after supper, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in My blood which is shed for you.
22.21: But see the hand of him who betrays Me is with Me at the table.
22.22: Indeed, the Son of Man goes as it has been determined. But woe to that man by whom He is betrayed!”
22.23: They began to inquire among themselves which of them it was who would do this.
22.24: There was also rivalry among them concerning which of them was to be counted the greatest.
22.25: He said to them, “The kings of the Gentiles exercise lordship over them, and those who exercise authority over them are called benefactors.
22.26: But you are not so. Instead, let him who is greatest among you be as the younger, and he who rules as he who serves.
22.27: For who is greater: he who sits at the table, or he who serves? Is it not he who sits at the table? But I am among you as He who serves.
22.28: You are those who have continued with Me in My trials.
22.29: And I appoint to you a kingdom as My Father has appointed one to Me,
22.30: so that you may eat and drink at My table in My kingdom, and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.”
22.31: Then the Lord said, “Simon, Simon, listen! Satan has demanded to have you to sift you as wheat.
22.32: But I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail. And when you have repented, strengthen your brothers.”
22.33: He said to Him, “Lord, I am ready to go with You to prison and to death.”
22.34: He said, “I tell you, Peter, before the rooster crows today, you will deny three times that you know Me.”
22.35:
Then He said to them, “When I sent you without purse or bag or sandals, did you lack anything?”
They said, “Nothing.”
22.36: He said to them, “But now, let him who has a purse take it and also a bag. And let him who has no sword sell his garment and buy one.
22.37: For I tell you, what is written must yet be accomplished in Me, ‘And He was numbered with the transgressors.’ Indeed, what is written concerning Me has a fulfillment.”
22.38:
They said, “Lord, look, here are two swords.”
He said to them, “It is enough.”
22.39: According to His custom, He came out and went to the Mount of Olives. And His disciples followed Him.
22.40: When He came there, He said to them, “Pray that you may not fall into temptation.”
22.41: He withdrew from them about a stone’s throw, and He knelt down and prayed,
22.42: “Father, if You are willing, remove this cup from Me. Nevertheless not My will, but Yours, be done.”
22.43: An angel from heaven appeared to Him, strengthening Him.
22.44: And being in anguish, He prayed more earnestly. And His sweat became like great drops of blood falling down to the ground.
22.45: When He rose from prayer and had come to His disciples, He found them sleeping from sorrow.
22.46: He said to them, “Why do you sleep? Rise and pray, lest you fall into temptation.”
22.47: While He was yet speaking, a crowd came. And he who was called Judas, one of the twelve, was leading them. He drew near to Jesus to kiss Him.
22.48: But Jesus said to him, “Judas, do you betray the Son of Man with a kiss?”
22.49: When those who were around Him saw what would follow, they said, “Lord, shall we strike with the sword?”
22.50: And one of them struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his right ear.
22.51: But Jesus said, “This is enough!” And He touched his ear and healed him.
22.52: Then Jesus said to the chief priests, and captains of the temple guard, and the elders who had come for Him, “Have you come out with swords and clubs as against a rebel?
22.53: Daily, while I was with you in the temple, you did not lay hands on Me. But this is your hour, and the power of darkness!”
22.54: Then they arrested Him, and led Him away, and brought Him into the high priest’s house. Peter followed at a distance.
22.55: But when they had kindled a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat down together, Peter sat among them.
22.56: Then a servant girl saw him as he sat near the fire, and gazed at him, and said, “This man was with Him.”
22.57: But he denied Him, saying, “Woman, I do not know Him.”
22.58:
A little later someone else saw him and said, “You also are one of them.”
Peter said, “Man, I am not!”
22.59: About an hour later another man firmly declared, “Certainly, this man also was with Him, for he is a Galilean.”
22.60: Peter said, “Man, I do not know what you are saying.” Immediately, while he was yet speaking, the rooster crowed.
22.61: The Lord turned and looked at Peter. Then Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how He had told him, “Before the rooster crows, you will deny Me three times.”
22.62: And Peter went outside and wept bitterly.
22.63: The men who guarded Jesus mocked Him and whipped Him.
22.64: When they had blindfolded Him, they struck Him on the face and asked Him, “Prophesy! Who struck You?”
22.65: And many other things they blasphemously spoke against Him.
22.66: When day came, the assembly of the elders of the people, both the chief priests and scribes, came together and led Him away to their council, saying,
22.67:
“Are You the Christ? Tell us!”
He said to them, “If I tell you, you will not believe.
22.68: And if I also question you, you will not answer Me or release Me.
22.69: From now on the Son of Man will be seated at the right hand of the power of God.”
22.70:
They all said, “Are You then the Son of God?”
He said to them, “You truly say that I am.”
22.71: Then they said, “What further testimony do we need? We have heard it from His own mouth.”

23.1: Then the whole assembly rose and led Him to Pilate.
23.2: And they began to accuse Him, saying, “We found this Man perverting our nation, and forbidding us to pay taxes to Caesar, and saying that He Himself is Christ a King.”
23.3:
So Pilate asked Him, “Are You the King of the Jews?”
He answered, “You truly say so.”
23.4: Then Pilate said to the chief priests and to the people, “I find no fault in this Man.”
23.5: But they insisted, saying, “He stirs up the people, teaching throughout all Judea, beginning from Galilee to here.”
23.6: When Pilate heard of Galilee, he asked whether the Man was a Galilean.
23.7: When he learned that He belonged to Herod’s jurisdiction, he sent Him to Herod, who was also in Jerusalem at that time.
23.8: When Herod saw Jesus, he greatly rejoiced, for he had desired to see Him for a long time, because he had heard many things of Him, and he was hoping to see some miracle performed by Him.
23.9: He questioned Him with many words, but He gave no answer.
23.10: The chief priests and the scribes stood by, vehemently accusing Him.
23.11: Then Herod with his soldiers despised Him, and mocked Him, and dressed Him in a fine robe, and sent Him back to Pilate.
23.12: On the same day Pilate and Herod became friends with each other, having previously been at enmity with each other.
23.13: Pilate called together the chief priests and the rulers and the people,
23.14: and said to them, “You have brought this Man to me as one who incites the people. And truly, I, having examined Him before you, have found no fault in this Man concerning those things of which you accuse Him.
23.15: No, neither has Herod, for he sent him back to us. Look, nothing worthy of death has been done by Him.
23.16: I will therefore chastise Him and release Him.”
23.17: For he was obligated to release one man to them at the feast.
23.18: But they all cried out at once saying, “Take this Man away and release Barabbas to us!”
23.19: This man had been thrown in prison for an insurrection in the city and for murder.
23.20: Therefore Pilate spoke to them again, desiring to release Jesus.
23.21: But they cried out, “Crucify Him! Crucify Him!”
23.22: He said to them a third time, “Why, what evil has He done? I have found in Him no cause worthy of death. I will therefore chastise Him and release Him.”
23.23: But they insisted with loud voices, asking that He be crucified. And the voices of these men and of the chief priests prevailed.
23.24: So Pilate gave the sentence as they demanded.
23.25: He released to them the man who was thrown in prison for insurrection and murder, whom they asked for. But he sentenced Jesus according to their will.
23.26: As they led Him away, they seized Simon of Cyrene, who was coming from the country, and they laid the cross on him to carry it behind Jesus.
23.27: A large number of people followed Him, including women who mourned and lamented Him.
23.28: Jesus turned to them, saying, “Daughters of Jerusalem, weep not for Me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.
23.29: Listen, the days are coming when they will say, ‘Blessed are the barren, who never bore and never nursed!’
23.30:
Then
they will begin to say to the mountains, ‘Fall on us,’
    and to the hills, ‘Cover us.’
23.31: For if men do these things when the tree is green, what will happen when it is dry?”
23.32: Two different men, who were criminals, also were led with Him to be killed.
23.33: When they came to the place which is called The Skull, there they crucified Him and the criminals, one on the right and one on the left.
23.34: Jesus said, “Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do.” And they divided His clothes by casting lots.
23.35: The people stood by watching. But the rulers with them scoffed, saying, “He saved others. Let Him save Himself if He is the Christ, the Chosen One of God.”
23.36: And the soldiers also mocked Him, coming to Him and offering Him sour wine,
23.37: saying, “If You are the King of the Jews, save Yourself.”
23.38:
An inscription was written over Him in letters of Greek and Latin and Hebrew:
THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
23.39: One of the criminals who were hanged blasphemed Him, saying, “If You are the Christ, save Yourself and us!”
23.40: But the other rebuked him, saying, “Do you not fear God, seeing you are under the same sentence?
23.41: And we indeed, justly. For we are receiving the due reward of our deeds. But this Man has done nothing amiss.”
23.42: Then he said to Jesus, “Lord, remember me when You come into Your kingdom.”
23.43: Jesus said to him, “Truly, I tell you, today you will be with Me in Paradise.”
23.44: It was now about the sixth hour, and darkness came over all the land until the ninth hour,
23.45: while the sun was darkened. And the veil of the temple was torn in the middle.
23.46: And Jesus cried out with a loud voice, “Father, into Your hands I commit My spirit.” Having said this, He gave up the spirit.
23.47: When the centurion saw what had happened, he glorified God and said, “Certainly, this was a righteous Man.”
23.48: All the crowds who came together to that sight, witnessing what occurred, struck their chests and returned.
23.49: But all those who knew Him and the women accompanying Him from Galilee stood at a distance, seeing these things.
23.50: Now there was a man named Joseph, a member of the Council, who was a good and just man.
23.51: He had not consented to their counsel and deed. He was from Arimathea, a city of the Jews, and he himself was also waiting for the kingdom of God.
23.52: This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
23.53: Then he took Him down, and wrapped Him in linen, and placed Him in a hewn tomb, where no one had ever been buried.
23.54: It was the Day of Preparation, and the Sabbath was drawing near.
23.55: The women who came with Him from Galilee followed, and saw the tomb and how His body was placed.
23.56: Then they returned and prepared spices and ointments. On the Sabbath they rested according to the commandment.

24.1: Now on the first day of the week, very early in the morning, they, and certain other women with them, came to the tomb bringing the spices they had prepared.
24.2: They found the stone rolled away from the tomb.
24.3: But when they entered, they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
24.4: While they were greatly perplexed concerning this, suddenly two men stood by them in shining garments.
24.5: As they were afraid and bowed their faces to the ground, they said to them, “Why do you seek the living among the dead?
24.6: He is not here, but has risen! Remember how He spoke to you while He was still in Galilee,
24.7: saying, ‘The Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and on the third day rise again.’ ”
24.9: And they returned from the tomb and reported all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.
24.10: It was Mary Magdalene and Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and other women with them, who told these things to the apostles.
24.11: But their words seemed like fables to them, and they did not believe them.
24.12: But Peter rose and ran to the tomb. Stooping down, he saw the linen clothes lying by themselves. He departed, wondering in himself what had happened.
24.13: Now that same day two of them were going to a village called Emmaus, about seven miles from Jerusalem.
24.14: They were talking with each other about all these things that had happened.
24.15: While they communed and reasoned together, Jesus Himself drew near and went with them.
24.16: But their eyes were kept from recognizing Him.
24.17: He said to them, “What kind of communication are you sharing with one another while you are walking and are sad?”
24.18: One of them, named Cleopas, answered Him, “Are You the only foreigner in Jerusalem who does not know what has happened there in these days?”
24.19:
He said to them, “What things?”
They said to Him, “Concerning Jesus of Nazareth, who was a prophet, powerful in deed and word before God and all the people,
24.20: and how our chief priests and rulers handed Him over to be sentenced to death and crucified Him.
24.21: But we were hoping that it was He who was to redeem Israel. Moreover, today is the third day since these things happened.
24.22: Even some women from among us, who arrived early at the tomb, surprised us.
24.23: When they did not find His body, they returned saying that they had even seen a vision of angels, who said that He was alive.
24.24: Then some of those who were with us went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said. But they did not see Him.”
24.25: He said to them, “O fools! And slow of heart to believe what the prophets have spoken!
24.26: Was it not necessary for the Christ to suffer these things and to enter His glory?”
24.27: And beginning with Moses and all the Prophets, He explained to them the things concerning Himself in all the Scriptures.
24.28: They drew near the village where they were traveling, and He seemed to be going farther.
24.29: But they urged Him, saying, “Stay with us. For it is nearly evening and the day is far spent.” So He went in to stay with them.
24.30: As He sat at supper with them, He took the bread, blessed it and broke it, and gave it to them.
24.31: Then their eyes were opened, and they recognized Him. And He vanished out of their sight.
24.32: They said to each other, “Did not our hearts burn within us while He talked to us on the way and while He opened the Scriptures to us?”
24.33: They rose up and returned to Jerusalem at once. And they found the eleven and those who were with them assembled together,
24.34: saying, “The Lord has risen indeed, and has appeared to Simon!”
24.35: Then they reported what had happened on the way, and how He was recognized by them in the breaking of the bread.
24.36: As they were saying this, Jesus Himself stood among them and said to them, “Peace be unto you.”
24.37: They were terrified and frightened, and supposed that they saw a spirit.
24.38: He said to them, “Why are you troubled, and why do doubts arise in your hearts?
24.39: See My hands and My feet, that it is I Myself. Feel Me and see. For a spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see that I have.”
24.40: When He said this, He showed them His hands and His feet.
24.41: And while they yet disbelieved for joy and wondered, He said to them, “Do you have any food here?”
24.42: They gave Him a piece of broiled fish and some honeycomb.
24.43: And He took it and ate it before them.
24.44: He said to them, “These are the words which I spoke to you while I was still with you, that all things must be fulfilled which were written in the Law of Moses and in the Prophets and in the Psalms concerning Me.”
24.45: Then He opened their minds to understand the Scriptures.
24.46: He said to them, “Thus it is written, and accordingly it was necessary for the Christ to suffer and to rise from the dead the third day,
24.47: and that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in His name to all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.
24.48: You are witnesses of these things.
24.49: And look, I am sending the promise of My Father upon you. But wait in the city of Jerusalem until you are clothed with power from on high.”
24.50: Then He led them out as far as Bethany, and He lifted up His hands and blessed them.
24.51: While He blessed them, He parted from them and was carried up into heaven.
24.52: Then they worshipped Him, and returned to Jerusalem with great joy,
24.53: and were continually in the temple, praising and blessing God. Amen.
